en.value: We're having a party!
Organising and inviting people to a party - "Many" vs. "much"
Are you coming to my party?
Here's a tip!
Everybody loves a good party! In this unit we're going to learn useful expressions to invite people to different events, as well as how to reply to an invitation. Let's get ready for the party!
Are you joining us for dinner tomorrow?
Can you make it to my party on Friday?
Would you like me to bring anything?
Do we need any more food?
Memorise the word(s).
Are you joining us...?
Are you joining us for dinner tomorrow?
Can you make it to...?
Can you make it to my party on Friday?
True or false?
Can you make it to my party on Friday?
This question is an invitation.

If we ask "Can you make it?", it means we are asking someone if they are able to attend a particular event. "To make it somewhere" also means to get to a place in time for something. If we're not able to attend an event we've been invited to, we say "I can't make it".
I just made it in time for the meeting.
Can you make it to my party on Saturday night?
I can't make it on Saturday.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Are you [k]joining[/k] us for dinner tomorrow?
making
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]Can[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]make[/k] [k]it[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]my[/k] [k]party?[/k]

If we receive an invitation to a dinner party, a wedding, or any other kind of event, it might include the initials RSVP. They stand for the French phrase "répondez, s'il vous plaît", which literally means "respond, please". If someone sends us an invitation that requires an RSVP we should let them know whether we can make it to their event or not.
RSVP by 20th October.
Yes! I'm in.
Another way of rejecting an invitation to an event is to say "I already have something on". But if we'd love to go we can also say "Yes! Count me in!".
Can you make it to my birthday party this weekend?
Yes! Count me in!
I'm sorry but I already have something on.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Invitation
Accept the invitation
Can you make it to my party on Friday?
Count me in.
I already have something on.
I have other plans.
Invitation
Decline the invitation
Are you joining us for lunch on Sunday?
I already have something on.
Yes! I'm in.
Count me in.
Do we have enough...?
Do we have enough ice or should we buy some more?
Do we need any more...?
Do we need any more food?
Select the correct question to the answer: No, we have enough.
Do we need any more soft drinks?
Do we have enough food?
Are you joining us to the party?
to have someone over
I have some friends over at mine tonight.
It's very common to say "at mine", meaning "at my place", or "at yours", meaning "at your place".
Should we have dinner at yours?
We're having dinner at mine.
to bring
Would you like me to bring anything?
I [k]have[/k] some friends [k]over[/k] at mine tonight.
join
in
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Would you like me
Do we need any
Do you have enough
to bring anything?
more food?
plates or should I bring some more?
Well done! Let's get the party started! But first, let's have another look at all the expressions we've learned in this unit.
Are you joining us...?
Can you make it to...?
I have other plans.
Yes! I'm in
Do we have enough...?
Do we need any more...?
to have someone over
Would you like me to bring anything?
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Are you joining Donna and me for dinner tonight?
I'm sorry, but I can't. I [k]have[/k] some friends [k]over[/k] at mine tonight.
Oh, that's a shame! Can you [k]make it[/k] to our BBQ on Saturday?
Yes! [k]Count me in![/k] I'm really excited for that!
It's going to be lots of fun. We have lots of people coming.
Would you like me [k]to bring[/k] anything?
No, I think we have [k]enough[/k] food and drink.
OK, let me know if you need anything else!
Ethan
Sylvia
[k]Are you joining[/k] us for drinks tonight?
Can you make
Sylvia is having dinner with Ethan tonight.
Sylvia can't make it tonight.
What's the reason why Sylvia can't make it for dinner tonight?
She's having friends over.
She's having a BBQ at her house.
She's having another party tonight.
[k]I[/k] [k]already[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]something[/k] [k]on.[/k]
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Do we have [k]e[/k][k]n[/k][k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]g[/k][k]h[/k] food?
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Do we [k]need any more[/k] drinks?
Complete the question to ask someone if they can attend the meeting.
[k]Can you make[/k] it to the meeting tomorrow morning?
Would you like me [k]to bring[/k] anything?
Complete the response to accept an invitation.
Yes! Count me [k]in[/k].
Imagine you're hosting a party - you've invited your friends and everyone can make it! Now it's time to go shopping. What do you need for the best party ever?
For a fun party, you need lots of ... / You also need some ... / The most important thing is ...
Grammar: Much, many, enough
Do you remember?

In English, there are two different types of nouns: countable nouns and uncountable nouns. Countable nouns can be counted (e.g. people, rooms or restaurants). Uncountable nouns don't have clear boundaries, which is why we can't count them (e.g. flour or water). Have a look below for a reminder.
Countable: Can we get a table for tomorrow?
Uncountable: Can I have some water?
Select the uncountable nouns.
[h]pasta[/h] car bike [h]juice[/h] party friends [h]water[/h]
Can I book a double room please?
This sentence contains a countable noun.
Let's look at how we talk and ask about different quantities of countable and uncountable nouns.
How many people did you invite?
I think we have enough food.
Marcus made too much pasta.
How many people did you invite?
We can ask about quantities with "how many" for countable nouns and "how much" for uncountable nouns. Here are some examples.
How many pizzas should we order?
How much juice would you like?
I'm not sure how much flour we need.
We cannot count the noun in this sentence.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
How [k]much[/k] pasta did you cook?
many
Do we have enough food for the party?
This sentence contains a countable noun.
We can use the word "enough" for both countable and uncountable nouns.
Do we have enough food for the party?
Do we have enough plates for everyone?
Do we have enough glasses for everyone?
You don't need to bring anything, I bought [k]enough[/k] food.
many
We use "too much" with uncountable nouns and "too many" with countable nouns to express that there's more of something than we need. Here are some examples.
I think he's used too much salt.
There are too many people in the kitchen.
Select the word we can use with both countable and uncountable nouns.
enough
many
much
I think he uses too much salt.
She invited too [k]many[/k] people, it's very crowded.
much
many
much
enough
countable nouns
uncountable nouns
all nouns
How [k]many[/k] people are coming to your party?
much
I bought [k]too[/k] [k]many[/k] apples.
how
much
Select the two words we use to ask for a quantity.
Have many people cancelled or will it be busy?
[h]How[/h] [h]much[/h] time do we have before the guests arrive?
I made too [k]much[/k] food.
many
Here are some common expressions we use "too much" with:
When we get an amazing gift: "Oh you shouldn't have, this is too much!"
When we don't really like something: "I don't like this music too much."
[k]How[/k] [k]many[/k] pizzas should I order?
Too
much
Complete the sentence to say you have the right amount of something.
We have [k]enough[/k] snacks, you don't need to buy anything.
too much
[k]How many[/k] people did you invite?
Do we have [k]e[/k][k]n[/k][k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]g[/k][k]h[/k] glasses for everyone?
Complete the sentence to say that you've got more than you need.
I prepared [k]too much[/k] food, you should take some with you.
Complete the sentence to ask for a quantity.
[k]How much[/k] rice would you like?
I invited [k]too many[/k] people to the party! There's no room.
We have [k]enough[/k] soft drinks but you could bring more crisps.
[k]How many[/k] pizzas did you order?
